metadata.case_name: Petitioners (Mine Owners) v. Respondent Local Board

facts.text: Petitioners are working certain mines situated in the district of Chhindwara.

Independent Mining Local Board constituted in or about 1926 for the area covered by the mines, included in definition of Local Board under Central Provinces Local Self Government Act, 1920, vested with powers of District Council.

Mining Board passed resolution on March 12, 1935, after previous approval of local Government, to impose tax at 3 pies per ton on coal, coal-dust or coke manufactured at mines, sold for export by rail or otherwise within territorial jurisdiction.

Central Provinces Local Self Government Act, 1920 repealed and re-enacted by Central Provinces Berar Local Government Act, 1948, with provisions for continuance of Local Boards and taxes existing at commencement.
Respondent constituted under 1948 Act as successor of Independent Mining Local Board.
Rate of tax raised by local body to 9 pies per ton in 1949.

Chief Executive Officer of respondent served notices of demand on August 23, 1958 on first and second petitioners for Rs. 21,898.64 and Rs. 11,838.09 respectively as coal tax for despatches from January 1, 1958 to June 30, 1958.
First challenge to validity of tax in 1957, though imposed since 1935.

Central Provinces Local Self Government Act, 1920 (Act IV of 1920) Section 51 empowered district council by resolution to impose any tax other than those in ss.24,48,49,50, with first imposition subject to previous sanction of local Government.

legal_issues.text: Whether the levy of the tax by the Independent Mining Board was invalid at the date of its original imposition in 1935.
Whether the levy ceased to be legal after coming into force of Government of India Act, 1935 and Constitution of India, 1950.
Whether the increase in rate to 9 pies per ton in 1949 rendered the levy illegal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Levy invalid in 1935 as contravention of s.80A(3) GOI Act 1915 requiring previous sanction of Governor-General for new tax not scheduled; Act passed without sanction; later modified to argue exercise of power in 1935 required sanction post-1919 amendment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.80A(3) GOI Act 1915 as amended 1919; Scheduled Taxes Rules

petitioner_arguments.text: Opening words of s.51 'Subject to the provision of any law...for the time being in force' made power subject to s.80A(3) and Scheduled Taxes Rules.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.51 CP Act 1920; s.80A(3) GOI Act 1915

petitioner_arguments.text: s.51 did not authorise levy of tax or cess of nature of coal tax, as it should be like taxes in ss.24,48,49,50 by ejusdem generis.
Tax ceased to be leviable after GOI Act 1935 and Constitution as exclusively leviable by Central/Union Govt, not saved by s.143 GOIA 1935 or Art.277 Constitution.
Even if saved by s.143, protection only for rate of 3 pies per ton pre-April 1, 1937; increase to 9 pies in 1949 illegal.

court_reasoning.text: s.51 CP Act 1920 enacted before GOI Act 1919 amendment introducing s.80A(3), with previous sanction under s.79(2) GOIA 1915; amendments did not affect existing laws; r.5 Scheduled Taxes Rules preserves right under existing laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validity of s.51 not affected; no need for fresh sanction for exercise of power.

court_reasoning.text: s.80A(3) procedural for future enactments, not applicable to exercise under existing valid law; r.5 Scheduled Taxes Rules confirms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No basis to read s.80A as limiting existing s.51.

court_reasoning.text: s.51 authorises 'any tax, toll or rate other than those specified'; ejusdem generis contra-indicated; coal tax authorised.
Saved by s.143 GOIA 1935 and Art.277 Constitution for taxes previously lawfully levied by local authorities notwithstanding exclusive central power.
Point on rate increase not raised in petition, not permitted.

holdings.text: Original imposition of coal tax in 1935 valid under s.51 CP Act 1920.
Tax continues valid post GOIA 1935 and Constitution by s.143 and Art.277.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art.32 for fundamental rights; Art.277 saves pre-existing local taxes.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Local Self Government Act, 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers local boards to impose taxes; basis for 1935 resolution.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Berar Local Government Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Re-enacts 1920 Act, continues local boards and taxes.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1915
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedural requirements for new taxes; sanction obtained.

statutes_cited.name: Scheduled Taxes Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Preserves local authority rights under existing laws.

outcome.summary: Court rejected all submissions of petitioners, upheld validity of original 1935 coal tax imposition and its continuance by successor local board; did not consider rate increase point as not raised in petition.

key_quotes.text: "Subject to the provision of any law or enactment for the time being in force, a district council may... impose any tax, toll or rate other than those specified in sections 24, 48, 49 and 50."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key empowering provision s.51 CP Act 1920

key_quotes.text: "Nothing in these rules shall affect the right of a local authority to impose a tax without previous sanction... when such right is conferred upon it by any law for the time being in force."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: r.5 Scheduled Taxes Rules preserves existing powers

key_quotes.text: "We, therefore, hold that the original imposition of the tax in 1935 was valid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
